- **Navigation:** Navigation Compose with bottom navigation
- **UI Framework:** Jetpack Compose with Material3 design system
- **Theming:** Dynamic Material3 theming, dark mode support
- **Interactions:** Touch-friendly with haptic feedback, animated state transitions
- **Accessibility:** High contrast support, semantic content descriptions, large touch targets
- **Architecture:** MVVM pattern with Repository and Use Cases
- **State Management:** StateFlow + Compose State integration

---

## 7. Example User Stories

- Scan product barcode, add to cart quickly
- Alert for low stock, update product easily
- Email receipt in PDF format after sale
- Export CSV for accounting
- Open dashboard and instantly see top sale stats

---

## 8. Sample Demo Data

**Products**

- Apple (SKU 10001, ₱30, stock: 100)
- Water (SKU 10002, ₱15, stock: 40)
- Sandwich (SKU 10003, ₱60, stock: 25)

**Transactions**

- Sale: [Apple ×2, Water ×1], cash, ₱75, [2024-07-11, 10:41:22]

---

## 9. Modern 2025 Android Tech Stack

### Core Framework
- **Language:** Kotlin 2.1.x (latest stable with K2 compiler)
- **Build System:** Gradle 8.x with Version Catalogs (libs.versions.toml)
- **Target SDK:** 35 (Android 15)
- **Min SDK:** 24 (Android 7.0)

### Architecture & DI
- **Architecture:** MVVM + Repository Pattern + Use Cases
- **DI:** Koin 4.0+ (Kotlin-first, lightweight DI)
- **ViewModels:** Jetpack ViewModel + Compose integration
- **State Management:** StateFlow + Compose State
- **Navigation:** Navigation Compose

### UI Framework
- **UI:** Jetpack Compose (latest stable with Compose BOM)
- **Design System:** Material3 with dynamic theming
- **System UI:** Accompanist System UI Controller (status bar, navigation bar)
- **Animations:** Compose Animation APIs (built-in)

### Data & Persistence
- **Database:** Room 2.6.x with KSP (Kotlin Symbol Processing)
- **Preferences:** Jetpack DataStore (Preferences + Proto DataStore)
- **Serialization:** kotlinx-serialization (JSON + CSV)
- **File I/O:** Okio 3.x

### Camera & Barcode Scanning
- **Camera:** CameraX 1.4.x (latest stable)
- **Barcode Scanning:** Google ML Kit Barcode Scanning 17.3.0+
- **Permissions:** Accompanist Permissions 0.32.0+

### Image & Media
- **Image Loading:** Coil 3.x (Compose-native with full Compose integration)
- **Image Selection:** Activity Result API (modern approach)

### Charts & Visualization
- **Charts:** Vico 2.x (Compose-native, multiplatform chart library)
- **Alternative:** Custom Canvas-based charts with Compose

### File Export & Sharing
- **PDF Generation:** Android PdfDocument API (native, no external dependencies)
- **File Sharing:** Android Sharesheet API
- **CSV Export:** kotlinx-serialization or OpenCSV 5.x

### Background & Async
- **Coroutines:** Kotlin Coroutines 1.8.x
- **Background Tasks:** WorkManager (for future cloud sync, report generation)

### Networking (Future Use)
- **HTTP Client:** Ktor Client 3.x (Kotlin-native) or OkHttp 4.x + Retrofit 2.x
- **JSON:** kotlinx-serialization

### Development Tools
- **Logging:** Timber 5.0.1
- **Memory Leak Detection:** LeakCanary 2.x (debug builds)
- **Build Configuration:** BuildConfig with variant-specific configurations

### Development Tools
- **Logging:** Timber 5.0.1
- **Memory Leak Detection:** LeakCanary 2.x (debug builds only)
- **Build Configuration:** BuildConfig with variant-specific configurations

---

## 11. Architecture Overview

### MVVM + Repository Pattern
- **UI Layer:** Composables + ViewModels
- **Domain Layer:** Use Cases (business logic)
- **Data Layer:** Repositories + Room Database + DataStore

### Dependency Injection with Koin
- **Modules:** Organized by feature (database, repository, viewmodel, network)
- **Scoping:** Singleton for repositories, ViewModels scoped to navigation graph
- **Testing:** Easy mocking with Koin test utilities

### State Management
- **StateFlow:** For reactive data streams
- **Compose State:** For UI state and user interactions
- **Navigation State:** Managed by Navigation Compose

---

## 12. Key Modern Practices Implementation

### 1. **Compose-First Design**
All UI built with Jetpack Compose, no XML layouts

### 2. **Material3 + Dynamic Theming**
Modern design system with system theme adaptation

### 3. **Type-Safe Navigation**
Navigation Compose with type-safe arguments

### 4. **KSP over KAPT**
Faster build times for Room and other annotation processors

### 5. **Structured Concurrency**
Proper coroutine scoping in ViewModels and Repositories

### 6. **Modern Camera API**
CameraX with ML Kit integration for barcode scanning

### 7. **Performance Optimized**
- Compose stability optimizations
- LazyColumn for large lists
- Remember for expensive computations
- Proper state hoisting

---

## 13. MVP Checklist

- ✅ Product management with Room database
- ✅ Camera barcode scanning with CameraX + ML Kit
- ✅ Cart/checkout flow with Compose UI
- ✅ PDF receipt generation with Android PDF API
- ✅ Inventory decrement/alerts with StateFlow
- ✅ Transaction history with Room queries
- ✅ CSV export with kotlinx-serialization
- ✅ Dashboard with Vico charts
- ✅ Material3 theming and dark mode
- ✅ Koin dependency injection
- ✅ Navigation Compose routing
- ✅ Offline-first architecture

---

## 14. Accessibility & Performance

### Accessibility
- **Semantic Content:** Proper content descriptions for screen readers
- **Touch Targets:** Minimum 48dp touch targets
- **Contrast:** Material3 high contrast theme support
- **Navigation:** TalkBack-friendly navigation flow

### Performance
- **Database:** Room with proper indexing and queries
- **UI:** Compose performance best practices
- **Memory:** Proper lifecycle management with ViewModels
- **Background:** WorkManager for long-running tasks

---

## 15. Code Quality & Analysis

### Development Standards
- **Static Analysis:** Detekt for Kotlin code analysis
- **Code Formatting:** ktlint for consistent code style
- **Architecture:** Clear separation of concerns with MVVM pattern
- **Documentation:** KDoc for public APIs

---

**Updated for 2025 Android development practices with Koin DI, modern Compose-native libraries, and current non-deprecated dependencies. Ready for professional development and production deployment.**

---

## Recommended MVP Feature Development Sequence (2025 Best Practice)

Following sequential thinking, industry experience, and your PRD priorities, the ideal order for
feature implementation is as follows:

1. **Product Management (Inventory)**
 - Build the product list (search/filter, add/edit/delete products, photo upload, barcode/scan if
 available).
 - *Reason:* Everything else (cart, sales, receipts) needs correct product data. This validates
 Room/database, DB<->UI sync, CRUD patterns.

2. **Cart & Checkout Flow**
 - Add/remove/update cart items, quantity adjustment, perform checkout, select payment type.
 - *Reason:* Core to daily POS usage. Exercises product data in “live” transactional context,
 tests state updates, and edge UX cases.

3. **Transaction History & Receipts**
 - List/filter past sales, show receipt/PDF, share/email/download actions.
 - *Reason:* Leverages both product and sales data. Implements historical persistence and
 archiving flows—verifies your end-to-end pipeline is robust.

4. **Dashboard/Analytics**
 - Show daily/weekly/monthly sales, top items, modern charts (Vico for Compose, etc).
 - *Reason:* Needs real transaction data. Surfaces business value and actionable insights for
 owners and staff.

5. **Settings & Branding**
 - Shop branding (logo/theme), CSV export, low-stock alerts, currency/tax settings, dark mode,
 preferences management.
 - *Reason:* Enhances user experience and branding. Typically decoupled from MVP flows and can be
 developed in parallel or after main flows.

6. **Stretch/Advanced**
 - Multi-user/roles (owner/cashier), advanced analytics, customer info capture, cloud sync, and
 any new priorities.
 - *Reason:* Defer until MVP is stable and tested; these build upon core foundation and add
 business differentiation.

**Approach:**

- Build feature-by-feature: Implement only the data models, repositories, ViewModels, and UI needed
 for each slice.
- Test each vertical slice in isolation (UI ↔️ ViewModel ↔️ Repository ↔️ DB) for rapid feedback and
 better quality.
- This iterative vertical-slice development keeps code clean, feedback loops tight, and features
 demonstrable after each step.

---

# Product Requirements Document (PRD): QuickPOS – Mobile Point of Sale

## 1. App Overview

**Name:** QuickPOS 
**Type:** Mobile Point of Sale (POS) for small businesses 
**Tagline:** "Checkout made simple – sales, receipts, and inventory, all in your pocket" 
**Visuals:** Cash register or scanner icon, green/blue accent, custom logo theme

---

## 2. Purpose, Goals & Vision

- **Enable fast, reliable sales tracking and checkout**
- **Automate inventory updates and error reduction**
- **Create professional, shareable receipts**
- **Deliver actionable sales insights directly on device**
- **Accessible, fast UX for any staff member**

---

## 3. User Personas

**Owner (Maria):** 
Wants to review sales, manage stock, see fast insights

**Cashier (Liam):** 
Needs fast product lookup/scan and checkout for customers

---

## 4. Key Features

### 4.1 Product Management

- Add/edit products (name, price, barcode/SKU, stock)
- Camera barcode scanning (CameraX + ML Kit)
- Photo upload (Coil Compose, optional)

### 4.2 Sales Flow

- Cart: add/remove/update products, quantity
- Fast checkout (choose payment type for demo)
- Auto stock decrement

### 4.3 Receipt Sharing

- Generate PDF receipt (Android PDF API/PdfDocument)
- Save, print, share via email/social/messaging

### 4.4 Transaction History

- List, filter, and view past sales
- PDF receipt preview/download

### 4.5 Basic Analytics

- Dashboard with today/week/month sales, top items
- Modern charts (Vico for Compose)

### 4.6 Utilities & Branding

- Export CSV of sales/inventory (kotlinx-serialization)
- Low-stock alerts
- Customizable shop branding (logo/theme)
- Dark mode toggle with Material3 dynamic theming

#### Stretch Goals

- Multi-user (owner/cashier roles)
- Hourly sales chart, inventory movement trends
- Customer info capture (for receipts)
- Cloud sync (Firebase or Ktor Client, later)

---

## 5. Data Entities

- **Product:** `{id, name, price, sku, barcode, stockQty, category, imageUrl?, created, updated}`
- **CartItem:** `{productId, name, price, quantity, subtotal}`
- **Transaction:** `{id, date, items: CartItem[], total, paymentType, receiptPdfUri}`
- **User:** `{id, name, role}`
- **Settings:** `{shopName, logoUri, themeColor, currency, taxRate}`

---

## 6. UX/UI & Visual Guidelines

- **Navigation:** Navigation Compose with bottom navigation
- **UI Framework:** Jetpack Compose with Material3 design system
- **Theming:** Dynamic Material3 theming, dark mode support
- **Interactions:** Touch-friendly with haptic feedback, animated state transitions
- **Accessibility:** High contrast support, semantic content descriptions, large touch targets
- **Architecture:** MVVM pattern with Repository and Use Cases
- **State Management:** StateFlow + Compose State integration

---

## 7. Example User Stories

- Scan product barcode, add to cart quickly
- Alert for low stock, update product easily
- Email receipt in PDF format after sale
- Export CSV for accounting
- Open dashboard and instantly see top sale stats

---

## 8. Sample Demo Data

**Products**

- Apple (SKU 10001, ₱30, stock: 100)
- Water (SKU 10002, ₱15, stock: 40)
- Sandwich (SKU 10003, ₱60, stock: 25)

**Transactions**

- Sale: [Apple ×2, Water ×1], cash, ₱75, [2024-07-11, 10:41:22]

---

## 9. Modern 2025 Android Tech Stack

### Core Framework
- **Language:** Kotlin 2.1.x (latest stable with K2 compiler)
- **Build System:** Gradle 8.x with Version Catalogs (libs.versions.toml)
- **Target SDK:** 35 (Android 15)
- **Min SDK:** 24 (Android 7.0)

### Architecture & DI
- **Architecture:** MVVM + Repository Pattern + Use Cases
- **DI:** Koin 4.0+ (Kotlin-first, lightweight DI)
- **ViewModels:** Jetpack ViewModel + Compose integration
- **State Management:** StateFlow + Compose State
- **Navigation:** Navigation Compose

### UI Framework
- **UI:** Jetpack Compose (latest stable with Compose BOM)
- **Design System:** Material3 with dynamic theming
- **System UI:** Accompanist System UI Controller (status bar, navigation bar)
- **Animations:** Compose Animation APIs (built-in)

### Data & Persistence
- **Database:** Room 2.6.x with KSP (Kotlin Symbol Processing)
- **Preferences:** Jetpack DataStore (Preferences + Proto DataStore)
- **Serialization:** kotlinx-serialization (JSON + CSV)
- **File I/O:** Okio 3.x

### Camera & Barcode Scanning
- **Camera:** CameraX 1.4.x (latest stable)
- **Barcode Scanning:** Google ML Kit Barcode Scanning 17.3.0+
- **Permissions:** Accompanist Permissions 0.32.0+

### Image & Media
- **Image Loading:** Coil 3.x (Compose-native with full Compose integration)
- **Image Selection:** Activity Result API (modern approach)

### Charts & Visualization
- **Charts:** Vico 2.x (Compose-native, multiplatform chart library)
- **Alternative:** Custom Canvas-based charts with Compose

### File Export & Sharing
- **PDF Generation:** Android PdfDocument API (native, no external dependencies)
- **File Sharing:** Android Sharesheet API
- **CSV Export:** kotlinx-serialization or OpenCSV 5.x

### Background & Async
- **Coroutines:** Kotlin Coroutines 1.8.x
- **Background Tasks:** WorkManager (for future cloud sync, report generation)

### Networking (Future Use)
- **HTTP Client:** Ktor Client 3.x (Kotlin-native) or OkHttp 4.x + Retrofit 2.x
- **JSON:** kotlinx-serialization

### Development Tools
- **Logging:** Timber 5.0.1
- **Memory Leak Detection:** LeakCanary 2.x (debug builds)
- **Build Configuration:** BuildConfig with variant-specific configurations

### Development Tools
- **Logging:** Timber 5.0.1
- **Memory Leak Detection:** LeakCanary 2.x (debug builds only)
- **Build Configuration:** BuildConfig with variant-specific configurations

## 11. Architecture Overview

### MVVM + Repository Pattern
- **UI Layer:** Composables + ViewModels
- **Domain Layer:** Use Cases (business logic)
- **Data Layer:** Repositories + Room Database + DataStore

### Dependency Injection with Koin
- **Modules:** Organized by feature (database, repository, viewmodel, network)
- **Scoping:** Singleton for repositories, ViewModels scoped to navigation graph
- **Testing:** Easy mocking with Koin test utilities

### State Management
- **StateFlow:** For reactive data streams
- **Compose State:** For UI state and user interactions
- **Navigation State:** Managed by Navigation Compose

---

## 12. Key Modern Practices Implementation

### 1. **Compose-First Design**
All UI built with Jetpack Compose, no XML layouts

### 2. **Material3 + Dynamic Theming**
Modern design system with system theme adaptation

### 3. **Type-Safe Navigation**
Navigation Compose with type-safe arguments

### 4. **KSP over KAPT**
Faster build times for Room and other annotation processors

### 5. **Structured Concurrency**
Proper coroutine scoping in ViewModels and Repositories

### 6. **Modern Camera API**
CameraX with ML Kit integration for barcode scanning

### 7. **Performance Optimized**
- Compose stability optimizations
- LazyColumn for large lists
- Remember for expensive computations
- Proper state hoisting

---

- ✅ Product management with Room database
- ✅ Camera barcode scanning with CameraX + ML Kit
- ✅ Cart/checkout flow with Compose UI

- ✅ Inventory decrement/alerts with StateFlow
- ✅ Transaction history with Room queries
- ✅ CSV export with kotlinx-serialization
- ✅ Dashboard with Vico charts
- ✅ Material3 theming and dark mode
- ✅ Koin dependency injection
- ✅ Navigation Compose routing
- ✅ Offline-first architecture

## 14. Accessibility & Performance

### Accessibility
- **Semantic Content:** Proper content descriptions for screen readers
- **Touch Targets:** Minimum 48dp touch targets
- **Contrast:** Material3 high contrast theme support
- **Navigation:** TalkBack-friendly navigation flow

### Performance
- **Database:** Room with proper indexing and queries
- **UI:** Compose performance best practices
- **Memory:** Proper lifecycle management with ViewModels
- **Background:** WorkManager for long-running tasks

---

## 15. Code Quality & Analysis

### Development Standards
- **Static Analysis:** Detekt for Kotlin code analysis
- **Code Formatting:** ktlint for consistent code style
- **Architecture:** Clear separation of concerns with MVVM pattern
- **Documentation:** KDoc for public APIs

## Recommended MVP Feature Development Sequence (2025 Best Practice)

Following sequential thinking, industry experience, and your PRD priorities, the ideal order for
feature implementation is as follows:

1. **Product Management (Inventory)**
 - Build the product list (search/filter, add/edit/delete products, photo upload, barcode/scan if
 available).
 - *Reason:* Everything else (cart, sales, receipts) needs correct product data. This validates
 Room/database, DB<->UI sync, CRUD patterns.

2. **Cart & Checkout Flow**
 - Add/remove/update cart items, quantity adjustment, perform checkout, select payment type.
 - *Reason:* Core to daily POS usage. Exercises product data in “live” transactional context,
 tests state updates, and edge UX cases.

3. **Transaction History & Receipts**
 - List/filter past sales, show receipt/PDF, share/email/download actions.
 - *Reason:* Leverages both product and sales data. Implements historical persistence and
 archiving flows—verifies your end-to-end pipeline is robust.

4. **Dashboard/Analytics**
 - Show daily/weekly/monthly sales, top items, modern charts (Vico for Compose, etc).
 - *Reason:* Needs real transaction data. Surfaces business value and actionable insights for
 owners and staff.

5. **Settings & Branding**
 - Shop branding (logo/theme), CSV export, low-stock alerts, currency/tax settings, dark mode,
 preferences management.
 - *Reason:* Enhances user experience and branding. Typically decoupled from MVP flows and can be
 developed in parallel or after main flows.

6. **Stretch/Advanced**
 - Multi-user/roles (owner/cashier), advanced analytics, customer info capture, cloud sync, and
 any new priorities.
 - *Reason:* Defer until MVP is stable and tested; these build upon core foundation and add
 business differentiation.

**Approach:**

- Build feature-by-feature: Implement only the data models, repositories, ViewModels, and UI needed
 for each slice.
- Test each vertical slice in isolation (UI ↔️ ViewModel ↔️ Repository ↔️ DB) for rapid feedback and
 better quality.
- This iterative vertical-slice development keeps code clean, feedback loops tight, and features
 demonstrable after each step.

package com.kyokosawada.ui.navigation

import androidx.compose.foundation.layout.Row
import androidx.compose.foundation.layout.fillMaxSize
import androidx.compose.foundation.layout.padding
import androidx.compose.material.icons.Icons
import androidx.compose.material.icons.filled.Home
import androidx.compose.material.icons.filled.List
import androidx.compose.material.icons.filled.Settings
import androidx.compose.material.icons.filled.ShoppingCart
import androidx.compose.material3.Icon
import androidx.compose.material3.NavigationBar
import androidx.compose.material3.NavigationBarItem
import androidx.compose.material3.NavigationRail
import androidx.compose.material3.NavigationRailItem
import androidx.compose.material3.Scaffold
import androidx.compose.material3.Text
import androidx.compose.runtime.Composable
import androidx.compose.runtime.getValue
import androidx.compose.ui.Modifier
import androidx.compose.ui.graphics.vector.ImageVector
import androidx.navigation.compose.NavHost
import androidx.navigation.compose.composable
import androidx.navigation.compose.currentBackStackEntryAsState
import androidx.navigation.compose.rememberNavController
import com.kyokosawada.ui.CartView
import com.kyokosawada.ui.DashboardView
import com.kyokosawada.ui.ProductListView
import com.kyokosawada.ui.SettingsView
import com.kyokosawada.ui.TransactionHistoryView
import com.kyokosawada.ui.WindowSizeClass
import com.kyokosawada.ui.WindowWidthSizeClass

/**
 * Type-safe sealed class for defining navigation destinations.
 */
sealed class NavDestination(val route: String, val label: String, val icon: ImageVector) {
 object Dashboard : NavDestination("dashboard", "Home", Icons.Filled.Home)
 object Products : NavDestination("products", "Products", Icons.Filled.List)
 object Cart : NavDestination("cart", "Cart", Icons.Filled.ShoppingCart)
 object Transactions : NavDestination("transactions", "Receipts", Icons.Filled.List)
 object Settings : NavDestination("settings", "Settings", Icons.Filled.Settings)
}

val navItems = listOf(
 NavDestination.Dashboard,
 NavDestination.Products,
 NavDestination.Cart,
 NavDestination.Transactions,
 NavDestination.Settings
)

/**
 * Adaptive navigation scaffold. Decides bottom bar vs rail and renders main NavHost for app.
 */
@Composable
fun AppNavHost(windowSizeClass: WindowSizeClass) {
 val navController = rememberNavController()
 val backStackEntry by navController.currentBackStackEntryAsState()
 val currentRoute = backStackEntry?.destination?.route
 val isCompact = windowSizeClass.widthSizeClass == WindowWidthSizeClass.Compact
 val isMediumOrExpanded =
 windowSizeClass.widthSizeClass == WindowWidthSizeClass.Medium || windowSizeClass.widthSizeClass == WindowWidthSizeClass.Expanded

 Scaffold(
 bottomBar = {
 if (isCompact) {
 NavigationBar {
 navItems.forEach { item ->
 NavigationBarItem(
 selected = currentRoute == item.route,
 onClick = { navController.navigate(item.route) },
 icon = { Icon(item.icon, contentDescription = item.label) },
 label = { Text(item.label) }
 )
 }
 }
 }
 },
 content = { innerPadding ->
 Row(modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize()) {
 if (isMediumOrExpanded) {
 NavigationRail {
 navItems.forEach { item ->
 NavigationRailItem(
 selected = currentRoute == item.route,
 onClick = { navController.navigate(item.route) },
 icon = { Icon(item.icon, contentDescription = item.label) },
 label = { Text(item.label) }
 )
 }
 }
 }
 NavHost(
 navController = navController,
 startDestination = NavDestination.Dashboard.route,
 modifier = Modifier
 .padding(innerPadding)
 .fillMaxSize()
 ) {
 composable(NavDestination.Dashboard.route) { DashboardView() }
 composable(NavDestination.Products.route) { ProductListView() }
 composable(NavDestination.Cart.route) { CartView() }
 composable(NavDestination.Transactions.route) { TransactionHistoryView() }
 composable(NavDestination.Settings.route) { SettingsView() }
 }
 }
 }
 )
}

package com.kyokosawada

import android.os.Bundle
import androidx.activity.ComponentActivity
import androidx.activity.compose.setContent
import androidx.activity.enableEdgeToEdge
import com.kyokosawada.ui.calculateWindowSizeClass
import com.kyokosawada.ui.navigation.AppNavHost
import com.kyokosawada.ui.theme.AppTheme


class MainActivity : ComponentActivity() {
 override fun onCreate(savedInstanceState: Bundle?) {
 super.onCreate(savedInstanceState)
 enableEdgeToEdge()
 setContent {
 val windowSizeClass = calculateWindowSizeClass()
 AppTheme {
 AppNavHost(windowSizeClass)
 }
 }
 }
}

})"},{"role":"assistant","content":[{"type":"text","text":"**Summary of current state and sequencing for feature development:**

- I have reviewed the PRD and codebase structure in detail. Navigation (Material3, Compose, adaptive bar/rail) is already scaffolded, and core screens for Product List, Edit, Cart, Dashboard, Transactions, and Settings exist as Compose placeholders.
- There is currently **no implementation** of Product data/model, Room database, Repository, ViewModel, or dependency injection for the Product Management flow.
- The project follows MVVM, Compose-first, Material3, and best Android practices per 2025 standards, but MVVM wiring and clean data/domain layers are not yet realized.

**Next sequential feature (per PRD + best practice) is Product Management. The steps are:**
1. Design the Product entity as a Kotlin Room data class with all relevant fields.
2. Scaffold Room database: ProductEntity, ProductDao (CRUD + search), and AppDatabase singleton, in a new `data` package.
3. Create ProductRepository abstraction over ProductDao, to provide all flows and suspending CRUD operations.
4. Implement ProductViewModel using ProductRepository, exposing flows for Compose, with add/edit/delete/search APIs. Use Koin for DI.
5. Update ProductListView and ProductEditView from placeholder to real Compose implementations using the ViewModel—show products, manage add/edit, and handle states.
6. Validate with sample/demo data per PRD.
7. This foundation enables following features (cart, sales, analytics) to be added cleanly, each as vertical MVP slices.

If you'd like to proceed, I recommend starting with **step 1: Product data model and Room entity creation.** Would you like to continue with this implementation, or do you have adjustments to the plan?"}]},{"role":"user","content":[{"type":"text","text":"

+package com.kyokosawada.data
 
+import androidx.room.Entity
+import androidx.room.PrimaryKey
+import java.util.Date
+
+/**
+ * Product entity for inventory management, Room integration (See PRD).
+ * MVVM Domain Model.
+ */
+@Entity(tableName = "products")
+data class ProductEntity(
+ @PrimaryKey(autoGenerate = true) val id: Long = 0L,
+ val name: String,
+ val price: Double,
+ val sku: String,
+ val barcode: String,
+ val stockQty: Int,
+ val category: String = "",
+ val imageUrl: String? = null,
+ val created: Long = System.currentTimeMillis(),
+ val updated: Long = System.currentTimeMillis()
+)
+

```
@@ -1,1 +1,30 @@
+package com.kyokosawada.data
 
+import androidx.room.*
+import kotlinx.coroutines.flow.Flow
+
+/**
+ * DAO for Product, Room persistence.
+ * Provides CRUD and search, Rx via Flow for Compose.
+ */
+@Dao
+interface ProductDao {
+ @Query("SELECT * FROM products ORDER BY name ASC")
+ fun getProducts(): Flow<List<ProductEntity>>
+
+ @Insert(onConflict = OnConflictStrategy.REPLACE)
+ suspend fun insertProduct(product: ProductEntity): Long
+
+ @Update
+ suspend fun updateProduct(product: ProductEntity)
+
+ @Delete
+ suspend fun deleteProduct(product: ProductEntity)
+
+ @Query("SELECT * FROM products WHERE name LIKE :query OR barcode LIKE :query ORDER BY name ASC")
+ fun searchProducts(query: String): Flow<List<ProductEntity>>
+
+ @Query("SELECT * FROM products WHERE id = :id")
+ suspend fun getProductById(id: Long): ProductEntity?
+}
+
```

+/**

+ suspend fun getProductById(id: Long) = dao.getProductById(id)
+}

+package com.kyokosawada.data
 
+import androidx.lifecycle.ViewModel
+import androidx.lifecycle.viewModelScope
+import kotlinx.coroutines.flow.*
+import kotlinx.coroutines.launch
+
+/**
+ * ProductViewModel for inventory feature, MVVM, Compose-ready.
+ */
+class ProductViewModel(private val repository: ProductRepository) : ViewModel() {
+ private val _products = MutableStateFlow<List<ProductEntity>>(emptyList())
+ val products: StateFlow<List<ProductEntity>> = _products.asStateFlow()
+
+ private val _loading = MutableStateFlow(false)
+ val loading: StateFlow<Boolean> = _loading.asStateFlow()
+
+ private val _error = MutableStateFlow<String?>(null)
+ val error: StateFlow<String?> = _error.asStateFlow()
+
+ init {
+ observeProducts()
+ }
+
+ private fun observeProducts() {
+ viewModelScope.launch {
+ repository.getProducts().catch { e -> _error.value = e.localizedMessage }
+ .collect { _products.value = it }
+ }
+ }
+
+ fun searchProducts(query: String) {
+ _loading.value = true
+ viewModelScope.launch {
+ repository.searchProducts(query)
+ .onEach { _products.value = it }
+ .catch { _error.value = it.localizedMessage }
+ .onCompletion { _loading.value = false }
+ .collect()
+ }
+ }
+
+ fun addProduct(product: ProductEntity) {
+ viewModelScope.launch {
+ try {
+ _loading.value = true
+ repository.insertProduct(product)
+ _error.value = null
+ } catch (e: Exception) {
+ _error.value = e.localizedMessage
+ } finally {
+ _loading.value = false
+ }
+ }
+ }
+
+ fun updateProduct(product: ProductEntity) {
+ viewModelScope.launch {
+ try {
+ _loading.value = true
+ repository.updateProduct(product)
+ _error.value = null
+ } catch (e: Exception) {
+ _error.value = e.localizedMessage
+ } finally {
+ _loading.value = false
+ }
+ }
+ }
+
+ fun deleteProduct(product: ProductEntity) {
+ viewModelScope.launch {
+ try {
+ _loading.value = true
+ repository.deleteProduct(product)
+ _error.value = null
+ } catch (e: Exception) {
+ _error.value = e.localizedMessage
+ } finally {
+ _loading.value = false
+ }
+ }
+ }
+}
+
```

+package com.kyokosawada
 
+import android.app.Application
+import com.kyokosawada.data.dataModule
+import org.koin.android.ext.koin.androidContext
+import org.koin.core.context.startKoin
+
+/**
+ * Application class for Koin startup and DI registry.
+ */
+class POSApplication : Application() {
+ override fun onCreate() {
+ super.onCreate()
+ startKoin {
+ androidContext(this@POSApplication)
+ modules(dataModule)
+ }
+ }
+}

<manifest xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
 xmlns:tools="http://schemas.android.com/tools">

 <application
 android:allowBackup="true"
 android:dataExtractionRules="@xml/data_extraction_rules"
 android:fullBackupContent="@xml/backup_rules"
 android:icon="@mipmap/ic_launcher"
 android:label="@string/app_name"

+ val products = viewModel.products.collectAsState().value

+ LazyColumn(modifier = Modifier.weight(1f)) {

+}

---

### Step-by-Step Plan & Execution

**Step 1: Product Entity**
- ProductEntity data class created as a Room @Entity with all PRD-specified fields.

**Step 2: ProductDao**
- ProductDao interface implemented, supporting CRUD operations and search by name/barcode with Flow return types for reactive Compose UI.

**Step 3: AppDatabase**
- AppDatabase abstract class set up with ProductEntity and ProductDao, as singleton Room DB provider.

**Step 4: ProductRepository**
- Abstracts ProductDao calls, provides suspend functions and flows for all inventory manipulation.

**Step 5: ProductViewModel**
- Exposes StateFlow for product list, loading/error/empty states, and add/edit/delete/search methods. Uses viewModelScope and is prepared for DI via Koin.

**Step 6: Koin DI Setup**
- Created Koin data module for AppDatabase, ProductDao, ProductRepository, and ProductViewModel.
- Implemented custom POSApplication class and configured Manifest for auto-injection on app start.

**Step 7: UI Refactor**
- ProductListView now injects ProductViewModel, observes real product data, and draws products with a LazyColumn (in Material3). Handles loading/error/empty states expressively.

---

**Ready for Next Steps:**
- Add functionality for add/edit (via dialog/FAB), barcode scanning, and integrating demo data.
- Expand UI interactions (edit/delete, search/filter) and Material3 UX polish.
- Sequentially proceed with next PRD features (cart/checkout, transaction history, etc.), all leveraging this clean MVVM base.

If you want to move on with further development (add product, edit, demo filling, navigation, etc.), just specify which area you'd like to focus on next—or I can recommend the next sequential slice."}]},{"role":"user","content":[{"type":"text","text":"<rules_context>

This is typically due to one or both of the following issues:

---

### 1. **Room is NOT added as a dependency, or not correctly synced**

Even though the PRD and `libs.versions.toml` specify that Room is required, your project must declare these dependencies in your `build.gradle.kts` (usually in `app/build.gradle.kts`) for the classes to be found.

#### Add these to dependencies (module: app/build.gradle.kts):

```kotlin
implementation(libs.androidx.room.runtime)
ksp(libs.androidx.room.compiler)
implementation(libs.androidx.room.ktx)
```

If you aren’t using KSP and only have kapt, you'd use:
```kotlin
kapt(libs.androidx.room.compiler)
```
But **KSP is preferred** per your PRD.

---

### 2. **Gradle Sync Needed**

If dependencies were just added or modified, you need to sync (Build > Sync Project with Gradle Files in Android Studio) before annotations and generated code like Room's classes become available.

---

### 3. **Import Statements**

You have the correct import statements for what should be available if Room is set up, so the problem is not here.

---

### Solution Plan

1. **Check `app/build.gradle.kts`** to ensure dependencies for Room runtime, KTX, and KSP/KAPT are present and correct.
2. **Sync Gradle** after confirming the dependencies.
3. **Rebuild Project** to see if the issue resolves.

---

---

## Diagnosis

1. **Room Library Is Defined in Version Catalog**
 - Your `libs.versions.toml` does declare the necessary Room artifacts:
 - `androidx-room-runtime`
 - `androidx-room-ktx`
 - `androidx-room-compiler`

2. **Room Is NOT Actually Used in App Build File**
 - In your `app/build.gradle.kts` dependencies block, there is **no reference to any Room dependencies**. This is why `@Database` and `RoomDatabase` cannot be resolved.

---

## Solution

### 1. **Add Room Dependencies to app/build.gradle.kts**

Add these references in the `dependencies` block:

```kotlin
// ROOM database dependencies
implementation(libs.androidx.room.runtime)
implementation(libs.androidx.room.ktx)
// Use ksp or kapt for the annotation processor:
ksp(libs.androidx.room.compiler)
```

- If you are using **KSP**, use the `ksp` line above (preferred if defined in plugins).
- If not, use `kapt` (be sure to add the kapt plugin to your buildscript):
 ```kotlin
 kapt(libs.androidx.room.compiler)
 ```

### 2. **Sync Gradle**
- After making these changes, run "Sync Project with Gradle Files" in Android Studio.

### 3. **Rebuild Project**
- Confirm the linter error for 'Database' is gone.

---

### Summary Table

| File | Needs Change? | What to Add/Change |
|-----------------------|--------------|------------------------------------------------------|
| `libs.versions.toml` | No | Already contains correct Room libraries |
| `app/build.gradle.kts`| **Yes** | Add Room dependencies under `dependencies {}` block |

---

Would you like a concrete code edit instruction for `app/build.gradle.kts`, or do you want to make the change yourself?"}]},{"role":"user","content":[{"type":"text","text":"

```
Unresolved reference 'plugins'.
Unresolved reference 'alias'.
Unresolved reference 'libs'.
```
that you see in your root-level `build.gradle.kts` file are **not caused by K2** (the new Kotlin compiler), but by limitations of the IDE's Kotlin/Gradle script support, especially for version catalogs and type-safe accessors in Gradle Kotlin DSL.

### Details:
- When you use `alias(libs.plugins.something)` or `libs.something`, these are features of Gradle version catalogs and type-safe project accessors.
- The Gradle build system itself recognizes these, but some IDEs and static analysis tools (such as the Kotlin linter) may show red squiggles or "unresolved reference" errors in `.gradle.kts` files, especially in the root build file.
- **K2** (Kotlin 2.x compiler) does not parse or affect Gradle build scripts—those are handled by Gradle's own build logic (which internally uses a bundled version of the Kotlin DSL compiler).

### Are they fatal?
- **No**: If your builds succeed when running from the command line (`./gradlew build`), and Gradle sync is successful in your IDE, these errors are IDE cosmetic/static analysis issues and can be ignored.
- They do **not** block your app code or K2 compiler from working.

---

### What can you do?
- Make sure your Gradle version is up to date (at least 8.x for full Kotlin DSL + version catalog support).
- If IDE errors are a problem, try "File > Invalidate Caches / Restart" in Android Studio.
- If builds fail from the CLI, then you have a real configuration issue.

---

**Summary:** 
- The errors in `.gradle.kts` are not caused by K2.
- They are benign and due to IDE or tooling limitations with version catalogs and the Kotlin DSL in Gradle.
- As long as builds and Gradle sync works, you can safely ignore these linter warnings/errors.

If you're seeing these errors during build (not just in IDE), let me know, and we can debug your Gradle setup further!"}]},{"role":"user","content":[{"type":"text","text":"

## 1. **IDE Gradle Script Parsing Issue (Most Common)**

- The majority of these errors occur for **Kotlin DSL** build files (`build.gradle.kts`) when the IDE (usually Android Studio) fails to correctly index or sync your build scripts.
- Common culprits:
 - Your Gradle sync is out of date or failed.
 - The IDE has not recognized your version catalog (`libs.versions.toml`).
 - Project structure is broken (missing configuration, or bad sync after moving files).
- If your build works via command line (`./gradlew build`), this is usually a **cosmetic IDE error** and not a blocker for actual building/running.

## 2. **Missing or Incorrect `settings.gradle.kts` Configuration**

For the `libs` alias and Kotlin DSL to work, your `settings.gradle.kts` must reference your version catalog:
```kotlin
dependencyResolutionManagement {
 versionCatalogs {
 create("libs") {
 from(files("gradle/libs.versions.toml"))
 }
 }
}
```
And your project modules must be declared.

## 3. **Corrupted IDE Index or Cache**

The Kotlin plugin and the IDE can occasionally get "stuck," leading to all references being marked as unresolved.

## 4. **Gradle Sync Has Never Succeeded**

If you haven’t done "Sync Project with Gradle Files" (or it fails with real errors), these references cannot be resolved.

## 5. **Incorrect Project Structure**

If your files are moved, renamed, or the project isn't opened at the root, Gradle Kotlin DSL may not find what it needs.

---

## **Steps to Fix**

1. **Check `settings.gradle.kts`** for correct `versionCatalogs` and module includes.
2. **Sync Project with Gradle Files** (in Android Studio).
3. **Restart IDE** and, if needed, "Invalidate Caches / Restart".
4. **Ensure you open project at the root directory** (not in a subfolder).
5. **Check for any real build errors by running**: 
 ```
 ./gradlew clean build
 ```
 from the terminal. If this works, your IDE errors are "false positives".

## **Are These Fatal Errors?**

- These do **not** block your code from compiling/running if the Gradle build system itself works.
- If CLI builds fail, you have a deeper configuration problem (missing files, wrong TOML path, etc.).

---

**In summary:** 
Your mistakes are most likely related to IDE sync and configuration, not due to errors in your Kotlin app code! Your actual build should work if the Gradle configuration is valid.

Would you like me to inspect your `settings.gradle.kts` for completeness, or guide you through resolving the IDE sync issue step-by-step?"}]},{"role":"user","content":[{"type":"text","text":"

This is why everything that references `libs` and `alias` is "Unresolved reference!"

---

## How to Fix

You need to add a `versionCatalogs` block to your `dependencyResolutionManagement` section and point it to your `gradle/libs.versions.toml` file.

---

### Edit your `settings.gradle.kts` to look like this:

```kotlin
pluginManagement {
 repositories {
 google {
 content {
 includeGroupByRegex("com\\.android.*")
 includeGroupByRegex("com\\.google.*")
 includeGroupByRegex("androidx.*")
 }
 }
 mavenCentral()
 gradlePluginPortal()
 }
}
dependencyResolutionManagement {
 repositoriesMode.set(RepositoriesMode.FAIL_ON_PROJECT_REPOS)
 repositories {
 google()
 mavenCentral()
 }
 versionCatalogs {
 create("libs") {
 from(files("gradle/libs.versions.toml"))
 }
 }
}

rootProject.name = "POS"
include(":app")
```

### Then:
1. Resync Gradle ("Sync Project with Gradle Files" in Android Studio).
2. If needed: File > Invalidate Caches and Restart.
3. If your IDE still shows errors, close and reopen the project.

---

Would you like me to propose this code edit directly to your `settings.gradle.kts` for you?"}]},{"role":"user","content":[{"type":"text","text":"<rules_context>

TITLE: Defining a Room Database in Kotlin
DESCRIPTION: The @Database annotation marks a class as a Room database. It requires specifying the entities, database version, and optionally auto-migrations, views, and schema export settings.

SOURCE: https://github.com/androidx/androidx/blob/androidx-main/room/room-common/api/restricted_2.5.0-beta02.txt#_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: Kotlin
CODE:
```
@kotlin.annotation.Retention(kotlin.annotation.AnnotationRetention.BINARY) @kotlin.annotation.Target(allowedTargets=kotlin.annotation.AnnotationTarget.CLASS) public @interface Database {
 method public abstract androidx.room.AutoMigration[] autoMigrations();
 method public abstract kotlin.reflect.KClass<?>[] entities();
 method public abstract boolean exportSchema() default true;
 method public abstract int version();
 method public abstract kotlin.reflect.KClass<?>[] views();
 property public abstract androidx.room.AutoMigration[] autoMigrations;
 property public abstract kotlin.reflect.KClass<?>[] entities;
 property public abstract boolean exportSchema;
 property public abstract int version;
 property public abstract kotlin.reflect.KClass<?>[] views;
}
```

TITLE: Configuring Room Database Executors (Kotlin)
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to build an in-memory Room database instance and configure its query and transaction executors using `setQueryExecutor` and `setTransactionExecutor`. Includes waiting for the custom executor to terminate, useful in tests.

SOURCE: https://github.com/androidx/androidx/blob/androidx-main/docs/testability.md#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: Kotlin
CODE:
```
val localDatabase = Room.inMemoryDatabaseBuilder(
 ApplicationProvider.getApplicationContext(), TestDatabase::class.java
)
 .setQueryExecutor(ArchTaskExecutor.getIOThreadExecutor())
 .setTransactionExecutor(wrappedExecutor)
 .build()

// ...

wrappedExecutor.awaitTermination(1, TimeUnit.SECONDS)
```

TITLE: Room Database Transactor Interface - Kotlin
DESCRIPTION: An interface for managing database transactions in Room, extending `PooledConnection`. It provides methods to check if currently in a transaction and to execute a block of code within a transaction of a specified type (e.g., DEFERRED, EXCLUSIVE, IMMEDIATE).

SOURCE: https://github.com/androidx/androidx/blob/androidx-main/room/room-runtime/api/2.7.0-beta01.txt#_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: Kotlin
CODE:
```
public interface Transactor extends androidx.room.PooledConnection {
 method public suspend Object? inTransaction(kotlin.coroutines.Continuation<? super java.lang.Boolean>);
 method public suspend <R> Object? withTransaction(androidx.room.Transactor.SQLiteTransactionType type, kotlin.jvm.functions.Function2<? super androidx.room.TransactionScope<R>,? super kotlin.coroutines.Continuation<? super R>,? extends java.lang.Object?> block, kotlin.coroutines.Continuation<? super R>);
 }
```

 method public abstract String[] ignoredColumns();
 method public abstract androidx.room.Index[] indices();

 method public abstract String[] primaryKeys();
 method public abstract String tableName() default "";
 property public abstract androidx.room.ForeignKey[] foreignKeys;
 property public abstract String[] ignoredColumns;
 property public abstract androidx.room.Index[] indices;
 property public abstract boolean inheritSuperIndices;
 property public abstract String[] primaryKeys;
 property public abstract String tableName;
}

TITLE: Defining a Room Entity Annotation in Kotlin
DESCRIPTION: This snippet details the `@Entity` annotation, fundamental for defining a database table in Room. It provides properties for `tableName`, `foreignKeys`, `ignoredColumns`, `indices`, `inheritSuperIndices`, and `primaryKeys` to fully configure the table's structure and constraints.

SOURCE: https://github.com/androidx/androidx/blob/androidx-main/room/room-common/bcv/native/current.txt#_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: Kotlin
CODE:

========================
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
========================
TOPIC: androidx.compose.runtime.annotation
Q: Why are annotations in androidx.compose.runtime.annotation published in a separate library?
A: Annotations in the androidx.compose.runtime.annotation package are published in a separate library to allow their usage in modules that do not depend on Compose Runtime. This separation facilitates using these annotations in modules that might interact with Compose in other parts of the project without requiring a full Compose Runtime dependency.


SOURCE: https://github.com/androidx/androidx/blob/androidx-main/compose/runtime/runtime-annotation/src/commonMain/kotlin/androidx/compose/runtime/annotation/compose-runtime-annotation-documentation.md#_qa_1

----------------------------------------

TOPIC: API Guidelines for Jetpack Compose
Q: Should Jetpack Compose library and app development follow the baseline Kotlin Coding Conventions?
A: Jetpack Compose Library and app development SHOULD also follow the baseline Kotlin Coding Conventions. This promotes consistency within the broader Kotlin ecosystem.


SOURCE: https://github.com/androidx/androidx/blob/androidx-main/compose/docs/compose-api-guidelines.md#_qa_3

----------------------------------------

TOPIC: Kotlinx immutable collections
Q: What was the primary concern that led to the shading of kotlinx.collections.immutable in AndroidX?
A: The primary concern was the potential for binary compatibility issues. If Compose depended on the library and upstream breaking changes occurred, users could end up with conflicting versions on their classpath.


SOURCE: https://github.com/androidx/androidx/blob/androidx-main/compose/runtime/runtime/src/commonMain/kotlin/androidx/compose/runtime/external/kotlinx/collections/immutable/README.md#_qa_2

----------------------------------------

TOPIC: Kotlinx immutable collections
Q: Why was the kotlinx.collections.immutable library shaded when imported into AndroidX?
A: The kotlinx.collections.immutable library was shaded to avoid binary compatibility issues. JetBrains raised a concern that Compose depending on it could lead to problems if breaking changes occurred upstream, causing users to have conflicting versions of the library on their classpath.


SOURCE: https://github.com/androidx/androidx/blob/androidx-main/compose/runtime/runtime/src/commonMain/kotlin/androidx/compose/runtime/external/kotlinx/collections/immutable/README.md#_qa_0

----------------------------------------

TOPIC: API Guidelines for @Composable Components in Jetpack Compose
Q: What is the recommended approach for handling styling dependencies in Jetpack Compose components?
A: It is recommended to prefer multiple distinct components over style classes for managing dependencies. This approach promotes better modularity and reusability within Jetpack Compose applications.


SOURCE: https://github.com/androidx/androidx/blob/androidx-main/compose/docs/compose-component-api-guidelines.md#_qa_3

----------------------------------------

TOPIC: AndroidX Compose Runtime Documentation
Q: What is the role of the AbstractApplier class in Jetpack Compose runtime?
A: AbstractApplier is an abstract base class that implements the Applier interface. It provides a default implementation for some methods and requires subclasses to implement abstract methods like onClear.


SOURCE: https://github.com/androidx/androidx/blob/androidx-main/compose/runtime/runtime/api/restricted_1.4.0-beta01.txt#_qa_1

----------------------------------------

TOPIC: androidx.compose.runtime Package
Q: What are the CompositionLocal APIs found in the androidx.compose.runtime package?
A: The androidx.compose.runtime package provides CompositionLocal APIs, including compositionLocalOf, which allow for the efficient passing of data down the composable tree.


SOURCE: https://github.com/androidx/androidx/blob/androidx-main/compose/runtime/runtime/src/commonMain/kotlin/androidx/compose/runtime/compose-runtime-documentation.md#_qa_3

----------------------------------------

TOPIC: AndroidX Compose Runtime Documentation
Q: What is the role of `AbstractApplier` in Jetpack Compose runtime?
A: `AbstractApplier` provides a base implementation for the `Applier` interface. It offers default implementations for some methods and requires subclasses to implement abstract methods related to node operations and clearing.


SOURCE: https://github.com/androidx/androidx/blob/androidx-main/compose/runtime/runtime/api/restricted_1.2.0-beta01.txt#_qa_1

----------------------------------------

TOPIC: androidx.compose.runtime Package
Q: What are the Composition related APIs in the androidx.compose.runtime package?
A: The androidx.compose.runtime package offers Composition related APIs such as Composition, Recomposer, ComposeNode, and RecomposeScope for managing the composition lifecycle.


SOURCE: https://github.com/androidx/androidx/blob/androidx-main/compose/runtime/runtime/src/commonMain/kotlin/androidx/compose/runtime/compose-runtime-documentation.md#_qa_4

----------------------------------------

TOPIC: AndroidX Benchmark Native CMake Configuration
Q: What is required to load a library into an Android app from Java/Kotlin using CMake?
A: To load a library into an Android app from Java or Kotlin, you must call System.loadLibrary() and provide the name of the library as defined in the CMakeLists.txt file.

However, if the IDE still shows "Unresolved reference: ksp" even after this edit, here are the **sequential steps** (with reasoning and context7-backed best practices):

---

### 1. **Ensure Version Catalog for KSP is Enabled and Correct**

You've set up:
```toml
[plugins]
ksp = { id = "com.google.devtools.ksp", version.ref = "ksp" }
```
in `libs.versions.toml`, and it is referenced in both your root and app build files. This matches the Room and AndroidX guidelines.

---

### 2. **Root Build File Sets KSP `apply false`**

Your root-level build.gradle.kts:
```kotlin
plugins {
 alias(libs.plugins.android.application) apply false
 alias(libs.plugins.kotlin.android) apply false
 alias(libs.plugins.kotlin.compose) apply false
 alias(libs.plugins.ksp) apply false
}
```
Correct; this exposes the plugin to subprojects.

---

### 3. **App Build File Applies KSP Plugin**

Your app-level build.gradle.kts should now contain:
```kotlin
plugins {
 alias(libs.plugins.android.application)
 alias(libs.plugins.kotlin.android)
 alias(libs.plugins.kotlin.compose)
 alias(libs.plugins.ksp)
}
```
This is the recommended approach.

---

### 4. **Sync Project and Restart IDE**

If you still get "Unresolved reference: ksp" (even after edits), follow these steps:

- **Sync Project with Gradle Files** (this forces Gradle to update project model)
- **Invalidate Caches and Restart** (in Android Studio: `File > Invalidate Caches / Restart`)
- Fully **close and reopen your IDE** if needed.

---

### 5. **Check for Real vs. Cosmetic Errors**

Run from CLI to see if build works:
```shell
./gradlew clean build
```
If the build passes, the error is IDE/caching related. If it fails, paste the CLI output.

---

### 6. **Version Checks**

- Ensure your Android Gradle Plugin (AGP) and Gradle Wrapper are up to date (AGP 8.0+ recommended).
- KSP is not supported in very old Gradle or AGP versions.

---

**Summary:**
- Your config matches latest Room/KSP/Context7 guidance (see [Room docs](https://developer.android.com/training/data-storage/room#add-annotations)).
- Structural errors may persist if IDE is not synced. Sequential steps are: edit, sync, restart IDE, verify with CLI build.

---

If issues persist after these steps, please provide your Gradle CLI build output. 
Would you like me to walk you through updating AGP/Gradle or diagnose based on CLI output?"}]},{"role":"user","content":[{"type":"text","text":"

## How to Fix

### 1. **Add Koin dependencies to `app/build.gradle.kts`**

Based on your `libs.versions.toml` and best practices for Android MVVM + DI with Koin (including ViewModel support for Jetpack Compose), you should add:

```kotlin
// KOIN Dependency Injection (for Compose and ViewModel)
implementation(libs.koin.android)
implementation(libs.koin.androidx.compose)
implementation(libs.koin.androidx.navigation)
implementation(libs.koin.core)
```

If you have a bundle in your version catalog named `koin`, you could use:
```kotlin
implementation(libs.bundles.koin)
```
but explicit individual lines are clearer—especially for diagnosis and initial setup.

---

### 2. **Sync Project with Gradle Files**
After saving these changes, sync Gradle for the IDE to resolve references.

---

### 3. **Rebuild Project**
This ensures all Koin-related references for DI, `module`, `single`, and `viewModel` become available.

TITLE: Acceptable DSL Usage for LazyListScope in Jetpack Compose
DESCRIPTION: Presents a justified use case for DSLs, specifically with LazyColumn and LazyListScope. DSLs are acceptable when lazy composition of children and flexibility with different data types (e.g., sticky headers, items) are required, as they allow the component to compose only a subset of children lazily.

SOURCE: https://github.com/androidx/androidx/blob/androidx-main/compose/docs/compose-component-api-guidelines.md#_snippet_49

LANGUAGE: Kotlin
CODE:
```
@Composable
fun LazyColumn(
 content: LazyListScope.() -> Unit
) {}

// usage: DSL is fine since it allows Lazycolumn to lazily compose the subset of children
LazyColumn {
 // allow to define different types of children and treat them differently
 // since sticky header can act both like an item and a sticky header
 stickyHeader {
 Text("Header")
 }
 items(...) {
 Text($index)
 }
}
```

TITLE: Extending Jetpack Compose Component API with New Parameters (Kotlin)
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the recommended workflow for adding a new parameter to an existing Jetpack Compose @Composable function while maintaining binary and source compatibility. It involves creating a new overload with the default parameter and deprecating the old function with DeprecationLevel.HIDDEN to call the new one.

SOURCE: https://github.com/androidx/androidx/blob/androidx-main/compose/docs/compose-component-api-guidelines.md#_snippet_56

LANGUAGE: Kotlin
CODE:
```
// existing API we want to extend
@Deprecated(
 "Maintained for compatibility purposes. Use another overload",
 level = DeprecationLevel.HIDDEN
)
@Composable
fun Badge(color: Color) {}

// new overload has to be created
@Composable
fun Badge(
 color: Color,
 // default should be provided
 secondaryColor: Color = Color.Blue
) {}
```

 tabs: TabRowScope.() -> Unit
) {}

 // Can be a @composable as well
 fun tab(tabContent: @Composable () -> Unit)
}

TITLE: Simpler API for Lazy Composition with HorizontalPager in Jetpack Compose
DESCRIPTION: Shows a simpler, non-DSL API for components that still require lazy composition, such as HorizontalPager. This approach uses a plain @Composable (pageIndex: Int) -> Unit lambda, making the API easier to learn and use while retaining lazy page composition without the need for a DSL.

SOURCE: https://github.com/androidx/androidx/blob/androidx-main/compose/docs/compose-component-api-guidelines.md#_snippet_50

LANGUAGE: Kotlin
CODE:
```
@Composable
fun HorizontalPager(
 // pager still lazily composes pages when needed
 // but the api is simpler and easier to use; no need for DSL
 pageContent: @Composable (pageIndex: Int) -> Unit
) {}
```

TITLE: Prefer Slot APIs over DSL for Component Content
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the preferred approach of using simple composable lambda slots instead of DSL-based slots for defining component content. This simplifies API learning and support.

SOURCE: https://github.com/androidx/androidx/blob/androidx-main/compose/docs/compose-component-api-guidelines.md#_snippet_37

LANGUAGE: kotlin
CODE:
```
@Composable
fun TabRow(
 tabs: @Composable () -> Unit
) {}

@Composable
fun Tab(...)

// usage
TabRow {
 tabsData.forEach { data ->
 Tab(...)
 }
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Allow DSL for Lazy Composition Scenarios
DESCRIPTION: Shows an allowed use case for DSL-based slots in components like LazyColumn, where laziness and flexibility with different data types are required for efficient composition.

SOURCE: https://github.com/androidx/androidx/blob/androidx-main/compose/docs/compose-component-api-guidelines.md#_snippet_39

LANGUAGE: kotlin
CODE:
```
@Composable
fun LazyColumn(
 content: LazyListScope.() -> Unit
) {}

// usage: DSL is fine since it allows Lazycolumn to lazily compose the subset of children
LazyColumn {
 // allow to define different types of children and treat them differently
 // since sticky header can act both like an item and a sticky header
 stickyHeader {
 Text("Header")
 }
 items(...) {
 Text($index)
 }
}
```

TITLE: API Evolution: Adding Parameters to Composables
DESCRIPTION: When evolving component APIs, parameters must not be removed. New parameters must have default values. A recommended workflow involves creating a new overload with the default parameter, deprecating the old function with DeprecationLevel.Hidden, and having the deprecated version call the new one to maintain binary compatibility.

SOURCE: https://github.com/androidx/androidx/blob/androidx-main/compose/docs/compose-component-api-guidelines.md#_snippet_48

LANGUAGE: kotlin
CODE:
```
// existing API we want to extend
@Deprecated(
 "Maintained for compatibility purposes. Use another overload",
 level = DeprecationLevel.HIDDEN
)
@Composable
fun Badge(color: Color) {}

// new overload has to be created
@Composable
fun Badge(
 color: Color,
 // default should be provided
 secondaryColor: Color = Color.Blue
) {
 // Implementation using color and secondaryColor
}
```

TITLE: Jetpack Compose: Providing Default State for Composables
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates the recommended approach for providing a default state implementation to a Composable function. By using `remember { VerticalScrollerState() }` as a default argument, developers ensure consistent behavior and discourage private contracts between composable functions and hoisted state objects.

SOURCE: https://github.com/androidx/androidx/blob/androidx-main/compose/docs/compose-api-guidelines.md#_snippet_29

LANGUAGE: kotlin
CODE:
```
@Composable
fun VerticalScroller(

TITLE: State<T> Parameter Alternatives in Compose
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates discouraged and recommended ways to handle parameters of type State<T> in Jetpack Compose. Passing plain values or lambdas is preferred over direct State<T> parameters to avoid unnecessary recompositions and offer greater flexibility.

SOURCE: https://github.com/androidx/androidx/blob/androidx-main/compose/docs/compose-component-api-guidelines.md#_snippet_27

LANGUAGE: kotlin
CODE:
```
fun Badge(position: State<Dp>) {}

// not possible since only State<T> is allowed
Badge(position = scrollState.offset) // DOES NOT COMPILE
```

LANGUAGE: kotlin
CODE:
```
fun Badge(position: () -> Dp) {}

// works ok
Badge(position = { scrollState.offset })
```

TITLE: HiltViewModelKt Class API Reference
DESCRIPTION: This section details the `HiltViewModelKt` class, which provides utility functions for obtaining Hilt-injected ViewModels within a Jetpack Compose environment. It includes methods for creating ViewModel factories and directly retrieving ViewModels.

SOURCE: https://github.com/androidx/androidx/blob/androidx-main/hilt/hilt-navigation-compose/api/restricted_1.0.0-beta01.txt#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
package androidx.hilt.navigation.compose {

 public final class HiltViewModelKt {
 method @androidx.compose.runtime.Composable @kotlin.PublishedApi internal static androidx.lifecycle.ViewModelProvider.Factory? createHiltViewModelFactory(androidx.lifecycle.ViewModelStoreOwner viewModelStoreOwner);
 viewModelStoreOwner: The ViewModelStoreOwner to associate the factory with.
 Returns: A ViewModelProvider.Factory instance, or null.

 method @androidx.compose.runtime.Composable public static inline <reified VM extends androidx.lifecycle.ViewModel> VM! hiltViewModel(optional androidx.lifecycle.ViewModelStoreOwner viewModelStoreOwner);
 VM: The type of ViewModel to retrieve.
 viewModelStoreOwner: (Optional) The ViewModelStoreOwner to scope the ViewModel to. If not provided, it defaults to the current NavBackStackEntry or Activity.
 Returns: An instance of the requested ViewModel type (VM!).
 Usage: This is the primary public API for injecting Hilt ViewModels into composables.
 }

}
```

Q: What is the recommended practice for slot parameters in Jetpack Compose component APIs?
A: It is generally recommended to use single 'content' slot overloads for composable APIs. This simplifies the API surface and provides a clear entry point for defining the component's content.

`viewModel { ProductViewModel(get()) }` 
-- the Koin "viewModel DSL" method is **deprecated** for Jetpack Compose MVVM integration.

---

## Latest, Official Practice (per Context7 and AndroidX documentation 2024+)

### Compose + Koin 4.x/5.x

- **Koin's old `viewModel { ... }` DSL** for module definition is deprecated for Compose usage, because Jetpack Compose and ViewModel integration no longer require special provider wiring in modules.
- **Recommended:** Use a standard `single` or `factory` definition for your ViewModel in your `module { ... }`, then access it in your composable using `inject()` or the Koin-Compose API.

---

## Example: New Way per Latest Koin & Compose Docs

**1. In your Koin Module:**
```kotlin
val dataModule = module {
 single { Room.databaseBuilder(get<Application>(), AppDatabase::class.java, "pos-db").build() }
 single { get<AppDatabase>().productDao() }
 single { ProductRepository(get()) }
 // Replace deprecated viewModel DSL with factory or single
 factory { ProductViewModel(get()) }
}
```
- Use `factory` if you want a new instance on each injection, or `single` if you want a singleton ViewModel (rare for screen-level ViewModels).

**2. In your Composable:**
```kotlin
import org.koin.androidx.compose.koinViewModel

@Composable
fun ProductListView(viewModel: ProductViewModel = koinViewModel()) {
 // observe states...
}
```
- **`koinViewModel()`** is the official bridge for Jetpack Compose screens to get a ViewModel instance.

---

## Why Change?

- Compose now leverages its own lifecycle-aware `ViewModel` scoping.
- The old Koin `viewModel` DSL was for classic Android XML or Activity/Fragment wiring.
- Latest Koin and Compose integration requires only `factory`/`single` in DI, and `koinViewModel()` in screen composables.

---

## Next Actions

- **Edit your `dataModule.kt`**: 
 Change
 ```kotlin
 viewModel { ProductViewModel(get()) }
 ```
 to
 ```kotlin
 factory { ProductViewModel(get()) }
 ```
- **Inject in Compose screens** using
 ```kotlin
 val viewModel: ProductViewModel = koinViewModel()
 ```

---

## Why this fix?

- The Koin `viewModel` DSL is deprecated for Compose screens because Compose now manages lifecycle/scoping of ViewModels differently from classic Android (Activity/Fragment).
- The latest Koin+Compose best practice is:
 - Register ViewModels as `factory` (or `single` if you want truly singleton, but this is rare for ViewModels).
 - In your Compose screen, retrieve the ViewModel with `val viewModel: ProductViewModel = koinViewModel()`.
- This keeps your DI setup clean, future-proof, and fully compatible with Jetpack Compose navigation and scoping.

Here's a clear sequential breakdown and explanation of the entire implementation for your **Product Management feature foundation**, focusing on MVVM, modern Compose, Material3, Room, Koin DI, and context7-verified best practices.

---

## **High-Level Goals**
- Build a robust, scalable inventory system (Product Management) per PRD: CRUD, reactive UI, persistence, clean MVVM separation, and modern DI.
- Foundation for subsequent POS features (cart, transaction, analytics, receipt, etc.).

---

## **Sequential Steps & Rationale**

### 1. **Room Database Setup**
- **ProductEntity:** Defines what a Product is (id, name, price, barcode, stockQty, etc.), using Room annotations.
- **ProductDao:** Interface for all DB operations (get, search, insert, update, delete).
- **AppDatabase:** Singleton Room database definition to provide DAOs and manage migrations.

### 2. **Repository Pattern**
- **ProductRepository:** Abstracts DB operations, provides coroutine (suspend/Flow) APIs to the rest of the app—keeps data logic out of UI/ViewModel.

### 3. **ViewModel Layer**
- **ProductViewModel:** Manages product screen state for Compose UI. 
 - Exposes: StateFlow of product list, loading/error states, CRUD/search functions.
 - Connects Repository to UI in lifecycle-aware, testable fashion.

### 4. **Dependency Injection with Koin**
- **Koin Module (dataModule):**
 - Registers your Room database, DAO, Repository, and ViewModel for dependency injection (DI).
 - `single { ... }` ensures singleton objects (DB, DAO, Repository).
 - `factory { ... }` for ViewModel, following Compose best practice (since Compose manages ViewModel lifecycle).
 - **Why use Koin:** Cleanly inject dependencies, reduce boilerplate, improve testability and scalability.

### 5. **Modern Compose UI Integration**
- **ProductListView:** 
 - Uses `koinViewModel()` to get its ViewModel, observes StateFlows.
 - Displays product list reactively (LazyColumn), shows loading/error/empty states.
 - Foundation for add/edit features, further UI enhancement.

### 6. **Latest/Up-to-date Implementation Practices**
- **Room setup matches official Jetpack documentation as of 2024+:**
 - KSP for annotation processing.
 - Modern Gradle plugin configuration (using version catalog/aliases).
- **Koin ViewModel DSL replaced with 'factory',** and DI is done via Koin/Compose APIs.

### 7. **Gradle & Manifest Configuration**
- All necessary dependencies (Room, Koin, Compose, etc.) are added via version catalog and Gradle for robust, maintainable builds.
- Custom Application class starts Koin on launch.
- Manifest updated to use the custom Application.

---

## **Why this Approach?**
- **MVVM:** Separation of UI/ViewModel/Repository/DB makes code maintainable and testable.
- **Room:** Most robust DB/persistence library for Android; integrates with Compose/Coroutines/Flow for high performance.
- **Koin:** Simplifies DI, no boilerplate, Compose compatible.
- **Compose:** All UI written in idiomatic Kotlin, no XML, following Material3 expressive recommendations.
- **Future-proof:** Structure aligns with AndroidX/Google guidelines and community best practice; easily extendable for next features.

---

### **Summary for a New Developer or Reviewer**
- **ProductEntity**: Models product data.
- **ProductDao/AppDatabase**: Handles persistence and SQL APIs.
- **ProductRepository**: Mediates between DB and ViewModel; all business/data logic goes here.
- **ProductViewModel**: Handles screen-level state and logic for inventory UI.
- **Koin DI (`dataModule`)**: Wires it all together, makes dependencies automatic and testable.
- **ProductListView**: UI displaying products, fully reactive, future-proof for add/edit/search.

---

If you want details on any layer (how Compose UI maps to ViewModel, how Room CRUD works, lifecycle, testing, etc.), just ask!"}]},{"role":"user","content":[{"type":"text","text":"

---

## **Step 2: Implement Product Add/Edit Feature**

This completes the core "CRUD" functionality for product management and unlocks key business value for your POS MVP.

---

### **Recommended Sequence:**

#### 1. **UI/UX**
- Enhance your product list UI with:
 - **FAB (Floating Action Button)** for "Add Product"
 - Option to trigger "Edit Product" via item click/tap or menu

#### 2. **Compose: ProductEditView**
- Create or upgrade `ProductEditView` to use fields for name, price, SKU, barcode, category, stockQty, and optional image.
- Use latest Material3 components and best UX practice for input validation, error hints, and layout.

#### 3. **Connect to ViewModel**
- `ProductEditView` should:
 - Call ViewModel's `addProduct()` or `updateProduct()` for save
 - Communicate field validations, show loading/error feedback

#### 4. **Navigation**
- Wire up navigation from ProductListView to ProductEditView (and back).
- Use Compose Navigation best practice (type-safe, single source of navigation).

#### 5. **Optional: Barcode Scan/Photo Picker Integration**
- Consider allowing barcode scan and photo pick/upload during product creation/edit (PRD specifies CameraX/ML Kit and Coil for images).

#### 6. **Demo/Test Data**
- Optionally insert demo products to quickly validate CRUD and UI flows.

#### 7. **Testing**
- Manual and (optionally) automated tests for add/edit flows, error cases, and viewmodel/database responses.

---

### **Implementation Steps (concrete):**

1. Refactor `ProductListView` to show FAB ("Add").
2. Implement/add form-based `ProductEditView` with all required fields.
3. Link up dialog/screen via navigation, wiring save/cancel.
4. Connect actions to ViewModel and repository CRUD.
5. Test end-to-end in emulator/device.

---

### **Would you like to:**

```kotlin:app/src/main/java/com/kyokosawada/ui/ProductListView.kt, lines=ALL(1-75)
package com.kyokosawada.ui

import androidx.compose.foundation.layout.*
import androidx.compose.foundation.lazy.LazyColumn
import androidx.compose.foundation.lazy.items
import androidx.compose.material3.*
import androidx.compose.runtime.Composable
import androidx.compose.runtime.collectAsState
import androidx.compose.ui.Alignment
import androidx.compose.ui.Modifier
import androidx.compose.ui.unit.dp
import com.kyokosawada.data.ProductEntity
import com.kyokosawada.data.ProductViewModel
import org.koin.androidx.compose.getViewModel

/**
 * Product Inventory List screen. MVVM: State from ProductViewModel via Koin.
 */
@Composable
fun ProductListView(
 viewModel: ProductViewModel = getViewModel()
) {
 val products = viewModel.products.collectAsState().value
 val loading = viewModel.loading.collectAsState().value
 val error = viewModel.error.collectAsState().value

 Surface(
 modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
 color = MaterialTheme.colorScheme.background
 ) {
 when {
 loading -> Box(modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(), contentAlignment = Alignment.Center) {
 CircularProgressIndicator()
 }
 error != null -> Box(modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(), contentAlignment = Alignment.Center) {
 Text(text = error, color = MaterialTheme.colorScheme.error)
 }
 products.isEmpty() -> Box(modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(), contentAlignment = Alignment.Center) {
 Text(text = "No products found.", style = MaterialTheme.typography.bodyLarge)
 }
 else -> Column(modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize()) {
 LazyColumn(modifier = Modifier.weight(1f)) {
 items(products, key = { it.id }) { product ->
 ProductListItem(product)
 Divider()
 }
 }
 // TODO: Add FAB for add, or top bar menu for search/add
 }
 }
 }
}

@Composable
fun ProductListItem(product: ProductEntity) {
 Row(
 modifier = Modifier
 .fillMaxWidth()
 .padding(16.dp),
 verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
 ) {
 Column(modifier = Modifier.weight(1f)) {
 Text(text = product.name, style = MaterialTheme.typography.titleMedium)
 Text(
 text = "₱" + String.format("%.2f", product.price),
 style = MaterialTheme.typography.bodyMedium,
 color = MaterialTheme.colorScheme.primary
 )
 Text(text = "Stock: ${product.stockQty}", style = MaterialTheme.typography.bodySmall)
 if (!product.sku.isNullOrBlank()) Text("SKU: ${product.sku}", style = MaterialTheme.typography.labelSmall)
 }
 // TODO: Add icon/menu/row click for edit/delete
 }
}

```

</user_query>"}]},{"role":"assistant","content":[{"type":"text","text":"You are correct, and this is a common migration issue when switching to **Koin 3.x or newer with Jetpack Compose**.

---

## **Problem**

- `getViewModel()` is:
 - Part of older Koin DI APIs, mainly used with traditional Activities/Fragments or Compose <1.0.
 - In modern Koin+Compose, **it is deprecated and often not imported/included.**
- That’s why you’re seeing `"Unresolved reference: getViewModel"`.

---

## **Solution: Use koinViewModel() with Compose**

- **Replace** all instances of `getViewModel()` in your composable screens with `koinViewModel()` from `org.koin.androidx.compose.koinViewModel`

**How to fix in your ProductListView:**

```kotlin
import org.koin.androidx.compose.koinViewModel

@Composable
fun ProductListView(
 viewModel: ProductViewModel = koinViewModel()
) {
 // ... rest of your code ...
}
```

- `koinViewModel()` will automatically retrieve and provide your `ProductViewModel` from DI, scoped appropriately to the composing context (activity, navigation, etc).

---

### **Summary:**
- `getViewModel()` is not available in Compose/Koin 3.x+.
- **Use `koinViewModel()` instead**—this is fully supported and recommended.

---

```kotlin:app/src/main/java/com/kyokosawada/ui/ProductListView.kt, lines=ALL(1-75)
package com.kyokosawada.ui

import androidx.compose.foundation.layout.*
import androidx.compose.foundation.lazy.LazyColumn
import androidx.compose.foundation.lazy.items
import androidx.compose.material3.*
import androidx.compose.runtime.Composable
import androidx.compose.runtime.collectAsState
import androidx.compose.ui.Alignment
import androidx.compose.ui.Modifier
import androidx.compose.ui.unit.dp
import com.kyokosawada.data.ProductEntity
import com.kyokosawada.data.ProductViewModel
import org.koin.androidx.compose.koinViewModel

/**
 * Product Inventory List screen. MVVM: State from ProductViewModel via Koin.
 */
@Composable
fun ProductListView(
 viewModel: ProductViewModel = koinViewModel()
) {
 val products = viewModel.products.collectAsState().value
 val loading = viewModel.loading.collectAsState().value
 val error = viewModel.error.collectAsState().value

 Surface(
 modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
 color = MaterialTheme.colorScheme.background
 ) {
 when {
 loading -> Box(modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(), contentAlignment = Alignment.Center) {
 CircularProgressIndicator()
 }
 error != null -> Box(modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(), contentAlignment = Alignment.Center) {
 Text(text = error, color = MaterialTheme.colorScheme.error)
 }
 products.isEmpty() -> Box(modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(), contentAlignment = Alignment.Center) {
 Text(text = "No products found.", style = MaterialTheme.typography.bodyLarge)
 }
 else -> Column(modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize()) {
 LazyColumn(modifier = Modifier.weight(1f)) {
 items(products, key = { it.id }) { product ->
 ProductListItem(product)
 Divider()
 }
 }
 // TODO: Add FAB for add, or top bar menu for search/add
 }
 }
 }
}

@Composable
fun ProductListItem(product: ProductEntity) {
 Row(
 modifier = Modifier
 .fillMaxWidth()
 .padding(16.dp),
 verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
 ) {
 Column(modifier = Modifier.weight(1f)) {
 Text(text = product.name, style = MaterialTheme.typography.titleMedium)
 Text(
 text = "₱" + String.format("%.2f", product.price),
 style = MaterialTheme.typography.bodyMedium,
 color = MaterialTheme.colorScheme.primary
 )
 Text(text = "Stock: ${product.stockQty}", style = MaterialTheme.typography.bodySmall)
 if (!product.sku.isNullOrBlank()) Text("SKU: ${product.sku}", style = MaterialTheme.typography.labelSmall)
 }
 // TODO: Add icon/menu/row click for edit/delete
 }
}

```

TITLE: Material 3 Navigation Components (Android Compose)
DESCRIPTION: Showcases the usage of Material 3 navigation components (BottomNavigationBar, NavigationRail, ModalNavigationDrawer, PermanentNavigationDrawer) based on screen size and states, adhering to material guidelines for canonical layouts.

SOURCE: https://github.com/android/compose-samples/blob/main/Reply/README.md#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
// Concept: Adaptive navigation patterns based on screen size
Components:
- BottomNavigationBar: Used for compact devices with a maximum of 5 navigation destinations.
- NavigationRail: Used for medium-sized devices; can be combined with ModalNavigationDrawer for more content.
- PermanentNavigationDrawer: Used for large devices or desktops when ample space is available.
Dynamic Selection: The correct navigation type is chosen dynamically based on the device's size and state.
```

Glance AppWidget Development:
- UI Arrangement: Use Row, Column, LazyColumn.
- Data Loading: Use existing app repository to load data for the widget and perform updates.
- Refresh: Configure android:updatePeriodMillis to periodically refresh the widget.
- Styling: Use androidx.glance:glance-material3 library to create a custom color scheme with GlanceTheme and use dynamic colors when supported.
- Image Tinting: Tint Images to match the color scheme.
- Actions: Launch an activity on click using actionStartActivity.
```

TITLE: Enhance Adaptive UI for Android Apps with Jetpack Compose
DESCRIPTION: This section describes the updates made to Jetnews to improve its behavior across various mobile devices, emphasizing adaptive UI. TITLE: Run Instrumented and Robolectric Tests for Android App
DESCRIPTION: This documentation explains the process of running UI tests for the Android application. It distinguishes between Instrumented tests, which run on devices or emulators, and Robolectric tests, which run on the JVM, providing the respective run configurations and Gradle commands for each.

SOURCE: https://github.com/android/compose-samples/blob/main/JetNews/README.md#_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
Instrumented Tests:
- Run configuration: "Instrumented tests"
- Command: ./gradlew connectedCheck
Robolectric Tests:
- Run configuration: "Robolectric tests"
- Command: ./gradlew testDebug
```

TITLE: Jetsnack Custom Design System API References
DESCRIPTION: References to key classes and functions implementing Jetsnack's custom design system, including color palette, ambient, providers, and theme objects. This system does not use Material color theming but integrates with Material's shape and type theming.

SOURCE: https://github.com/android/compose-samples/blob/main/Jetsnack/README.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
JetsnackColorPalette: A class modeling the desired custom color system.
JetsnackColorAmbient: An ambient holding the current set of custom colors.
ProvideJetsnackColors: A composable function for providing a JetsnackColorPalette to the UI hierarchy.
JetsnackTheme object: Provides convenient access to the current theme colors.
JetsnackTheme composable: The application's main theme, which wraps Material components to use the custom color system.
JetsnackButton: An example of a custom component wrapping Material components.
Gradient: A collection of helpful Modifier extensions for applying gradients.
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Jetsnack Custom Layout API References
DESCRIPTION: References to custom Layout implementations used in Jetsnack to achieve specific UI designs. These layouts demonstrate advanced control over component positioning and animation.

SOURCE: https://github.com/android/compose-samples/blob/main/Jetsnack/README.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
CollapsingImageLayout: A custom layout used for collapsing image sections, as shown in the snack details screen.
SearchCategory: A custom layout for positioning an image and text items within search categories.
JetsnackBottomNavLayout: A custom Bottom Navigation implementation that animates the width of selected and unselected items.
```
